title: In Surprise, M.T.A. Bans All Tobacco Advertising
title_page: In Surprise, M.T.A. Bans All Tobacco Advertising - The New York Times
maintext:
Despite warnings that such an action might be unconstitutional, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday banned tobacco advertising in its subways, buses and commuter railroads.
The ban, which will go into effect as early as Jan. 1, could cost the agency $4.5 million in advertising income, officials said. The agency's annual budget is $3 billion.
"I have concerns about free speech," said Peter E. Stangl, chairman of the M.T.A. "But we also have an obligation to reduce the exposure of people, especially children, to a product that causes death."
The ban came as a surprise because the M.T.A. board had been expected to cut the amount of tobacco advertising it allowed in half. But board members said that, for a relatively slight difference in lost revenue, the ads could be banned, which they thought was better public health policy.
